title: 112_s1310
content: The "Dietary Supplement Labeling Act of 2011" may be cited as such. This Act regulates dietary supplements. The "Dietary Supplement Labeling Act of 2011" regulates dietary supplements by amending Section 415(a) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to include requirements for facilities manufacturing dietary supplements to register and submit additional information. The "Dietary Supplement Labeling Act of 2011" requires facilities manufacturing dietary supplements to register and submit information such as a list of ingredients and product labeling. Additionally, facilities must register new, reformulated, and discontinued dietary supplement products. Facilities must submit required information to the Secretary if they reformulate or discontinue a dietary supplement product for which they previously submitted information. Facilities must update their registration with the Secretary when making changes to a dietary supplement product, including providing necessary information within a specified timeframe. Facilities must update their registration with the Secretary within a specified timeframe when making changes to a dietary supplement product. Enforcement of this requirement is outlined in Section 403 of the Federal Food, Drug. Enforcement of registration requirements for dietary supplements under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to include penalties for facilities that fail to comply with registration information submission. Additionally, labeling requirements are established for dietary supplements. "SEC. 411A. Dietary supplements." The Secretary will compile a list of dietary supplement ingredients that could pose risks and seek evaluation from the Institute of Medicine within 18 months. The Dietary Supplement Labeling Act of 2011 requires the Secretary to evaluate the safety of certain supplement ingredients and establish warning label requirements for those deemed to pose potential risks within 2 years of receiving the Institute of Medicine's report. The Dietary Supplement Labeling Act of 2011 mandates the evaluation of supplement ingredients for safety and the establishment of warning label requirements for those with potential risks. The Secretary is required to update lists, warning label requirements, and ingredient weight disclosures as needed. Enforcement measures are also outlined in the Act. The Dietary Supplement Labeling Act of 2011 requires the Secretary to update ingredient weight disclosures for proprietary blends identified under section 411A(c)(1)(B) in the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. The Dietary Supplement Labeling Act of 2011 mandates the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a definition for "conventional food" within a year of the Act's enactment. This definition is crucial for ensuring proper labeling of food products, including information on adverse events, drug interactions, contraindications, and risks to specific subgroups like children and pregnant women. Additionally, the label must include the batch number for identification purposes. The Dietary Supplement Labeling Act of 2011 requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to define "conventional food" under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. This definition is important for proper labeling of food products, including dietary supplements that mimic conventional foods.
